Staff were extremely friendly, even letting us know that the carousel token vending machine was not working well and would likely just take our quarters without giving us tokens.

Overall, the concept is great - a sort of "look what you are missing out on" restaurant. Ah, if only the world would listen to Lennon, and have us imagine what life would be like if we could all get along. Hmmm. Until that time, I'm glad there's Conflict Kitchen - looking forward to this and other iterations of the concept. We are fans!

Will definitely be back

You have to go here. It's not just food but an experience as well. Their mission is using food and art to facilitate conversations around the cultures whose food they're serving at that particular time. 

In all honesty, I give the Iranian food 4 stars, some of which was a little inauthentic, but I know they try very very hard to make it so. They change menus, so we can't expect them to hire staff from the same ethnic backgrounds as the food either. The food really was good tho, promise. 

In any case, we need more places like this in the world.

Such an awesome concept! I visited Carnegie Mellon for the weekend and was told that this place was a must try. At the time I went, Iranian good was being served.
I got the Jujeh kebab (chicken). The kebab came with steamed rice, mixed pickled vegetables, fresh herbs, tomato and onion. It was very flavorful and the portion was perfect for what I wanted at the time. Loved that they have complimentary black tea. It helped me stay warm while I waited for my food. 
Wished that this place had an indoor dining area, would have made it that much better. 
Overall great experience and if I'm ever back in Pittsburg, I will be making a stop here.
In addition to the wonderful concept and educational endeavor that is Conflict Kitchen, I have eaten here many times and never had a bad experience. Amazing food, amazing project.

Overpriced for how much is offered.
The food can be good or s and so, depending on the cuisine.
I definitely recommend the Cuban Cuisine, which is the latest trend. So far the best cooking.
Great place for trying foods from countries the U.S. is in conflict with. Very friendly service.

First of all, food should never be mixed with politics. Second, hummus served here is horrible. In addition, the food from the "conflict" places is not original. Falafel balls should not be small and dry and eggplant should not be so smooth.

I still like your bolani, Conflict Kitchen, but why do you never seem to have the pumpkin one? Of your other three flavors, I still love the red lentil one the best. But show me some pumpkin love, please!

The service can be a bit slow, since one person takes the orders, makes change, and comes back out with the food.

Amazing concept and quality of food. Not good or picky eaters who may not like the cuisine.  bibimbop was great although they skimped on sauce and toppings and added a lot of rice.  Great for small bites

Passing through town and one of our planned destinations was Conflict Kitchen. Had heard good things.
First of all, love the concept! The food was good (chicken kabobs, and potato pancakes). Portions were a fair size, and the woman working there was just awesome. We'll stop there again!

This is more an art work than a restaurant. Featuring foods by countries that US is in conflict with. The food is worth it and the price is nice. Its not always %100 same as the taste in those countries but going there once is not enough. They always have some drinks specific to tje country they are featuring at the time which is nice. They are infact friendly people but more importantly they always have some thing for you to read about that country.

Hello Conflict Kitchen how nice to meet you.... I had no idea you were located in Schenley plaza. 
 
I am just in the area for a little music and after the 8$ Gyro I wasted my money on at the arts fest I am looking for a date with a new sandwich. 

Kubideh? you say hmm ground beef, with herbs sauce and lettuce on a tastey fluffy flatbread? I am not a beef eater and I loved it for 6$ it hit the spot and I could still feel the weight of my wallet in my purse. 

Yummt Iranian inspired at this time but I hear the cuisine affair rotates, veggie and non veggie options to please the book bag toting masses. 

I will definitely be back this was just the pleasant surprise I needed. Oakland is full of surprises like that.

Yum! I've always wanted to try Conflict Kitchen, but it was impossible for me to go because of the hours they previously had. Now they're open for much longer hours (I THINK 11-6), and they're located in Schenley Plaza! Win!
I've gone to the Iranian one twice already since they opened in Schenley plaza....last week. Yes, I like it so much I've gone twice in one week! I tried a number of things within in my two visits. I got the vegetarian sandwich...I do not remember what it was called. It was delicious, though a bit messy. I also tried the yogurt dipping sauce. The yogurt sauce was delicious, but the bread was the real winner here. It is kind of like pita...but salty and sweet kind of. I saved half of my yogurt sauce and plan to go back and buy more bread for it today!
I also tried the bread with cheese and walnuts. The bread here was a little dry--not sure if it's different bread or what. It was kind of hard and flakey...not at all what I was expecting. It was not bad, but I highly doubt I'll get it again even though it was the item I was most looking forward to trying.
The fruit drink was good, but a bit small. It was only a dollar, I think, but I'd have been willing to pay more for a larger option.
For dessert, I tried the rice pudding. For those of you who know arroz con leche...it is not at all like that. It's not sweet, but it comes with I think some kind of cherry sauce on top of it. Mixed with the cherries, it was a pleasant dessert, but I still love me some arroz con leche with cinnamon a bit more!
The staff was incredibly friendly and patient with those of us who had questions about the menu. While they were not accepting cards when I went, they promise that they will be accepting cards soon. I was told they would be accepting cards by this week, but when I went yesterday they still were not. Make sure you bring cash, just in case. It is a little pricey if you want to try a bunch of different stuff, but the sandwich itself would have filled me up for lunch just fine. The problem was that I wanted to try everything!!!
Finally, the CONCEPT. It is the coolest concept, and I really liked the informative paper that came with my sandwich. I saved it so I can read it later! I really believe if we all understood each other just a little better, there would be so much less war and conflict. And really, what's the best way to get to know a culture other than to understand their eating habits and traditions. I cannot wait to try other versions of this restaurant. I am hoping they bring back the Cuban version, and I'd also like to see some more Latin American versions. Aren't we pretty much always in "conflict" with that region?

The Cuban food this time around is ok, not amazing, but ok. I was expecting something different due to the hype. I could not order the beef dish since it was sold out. That should have told me to maybe wait for another day to try my luck. I purchased the pork dish and it was underwhelming. I do not know if it was just me but there was little flavor. The dish had pork and then rice and beans then a side salad. Since everything was thrown into a box together when I got to my seat it was all jumbled. The pork was mixed with the salad and the juice from both went everywhere. 

I went back to the stand and asked for some hot sauce. That really helped the dish. Overall I was not thrilled with what I got for the price.

Holy moly! I'm addicted!

I first heard of Conflict Kitchen back when it was in East Liberty, but I never got there. I think it's new location is brilliant. It's perfect for take-out food.

It's currently (July 2013) Cochina de Conflict, a.k.a. Cuban food. I freakin' love Cuban food. In fact, Pittsburgh should have a place for Cuban food, but I digress.

I got the congri, which is black beans and rice. You actually need a bit more black beans because the rice is supposed to be really black from the beans. Still it was good.

I also got the tostones, or fried plantains. These were excellent. If you've only had sweet plantains, you're in for a wonderful treat. I actually prefer them this way. They're salted like potato chips and served with a dip, and their dip is the perfect accompaniment. It was green and contained lots of garlic and black pepper. It was a bit sweet and citris-y--lemons or maybe limes? I actually poured a bunch of it on my congri because it was so good.

I sat down with my meal, and the woman at the table next to me said, "What the heck are you eating?!?" I told her. "WOW! That smells so good. I wish I had known about that because I just ate. That looks and smells 1,000 times better than what I had." So there you go. A review within a review.
I had the Afghanistan food. a bit of a line but it was super nice weather. they handed out a cool pamphlet with information on the culture of the cuisine to read while you wait!

Ordered the Chicken kebab and had high expectations after constantly smelling the food when walking by. Overall, the chicken had flavor but was a little dry. The dish could have used a dipping or yogurt sauce. It was very filling though and I did not feel heavy or unhealthy afterwords. Looking forward to when the country changes.

The minute I realized that Conflict was a block away during my visit - no way was I leaving without trying something off their menu. By now - all foodie's have heard of Conflict Kitchen - it's like "a thing" that's been mentioned in almost all of the food-related subscriptions I receive. 

Decent portions, cheap prices, backed with an amazing concept. You just can't go wrong.

Interested in good food?  Check.
Interested in learning about another culture? Check.
Interested in something different? Check.

The arepas are pretty good but I've only tried the vegetarian (queso fresco) and vegan (black beans).  There's a chicken and avocado one that scares me for some reason.  I don't know if it's because they're served cold or what.  Each arepa is $5 (cash only).

Why no five stars?  Because you have to stand and wait outside while they make it.  This would be fine during the spring and summer but as the temperatures are starting to drop it scares me to think of standing outside for close to 10 minutes while waiting for some food that I'm going to have to eat either outside, in my car, or wait until I get home.  

Oh, and they're only open 11:30am-2pm. I will be coming back every time they change their menu (I think every season it's a new country) but I may skip it in the winter.

Went here while they were serving Cuban food and was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the food, given the lack of good food around the university and it being rather inexpensive. On a nice day, you can take your food and sit at the tables in the park. The food is always changing and a really great deal for the money. I highly recommend giving them a shot for lunch and can't wait to go back.

Unique spot to grab a quick meal. They change their menu periodically to highlight the food of a particular culture, and they have videos playing to teach you a little about the peoples while you wait for your order.

It is not a restaurant but just a take-out counter out in the park, so you order, wait about 5 minutes, and find a place to picnic or grab a table under the large canopy nearby. When we visited, they were offering Cuban food and going by cocina conflicta. They had 4 entrees, two drinks, two desserts, and a few sides to choose from. I went with the pork, which came with rice, beans, and a side salad. The food is not spectacular but definitely solid for fast food, and reasonably priced. We enjoyed our meals and would love to come back when they change up the menu.

Bonus points for $1 bottled water.

It's a great concept. So much of culture is expressed with food and it is a great cultural experience. The food is really fresh and interesting. The staff is do polite and friendly. The outdoor seating is very relaxed. Over all a really pleasant experience.
I really enjoyed the lamb shank. And the drink was interesting and authentic. Very filling for a low price!

This is the best concept for a restaurant I've seen in Pittsburgh (or a lot of cities) in awhile. First, you should read all about it on their website and then follow it up with a visit. They showcase a different country who is in conflict with the US and represent peoples of that culture to explain what is going on within the country itself. Currently they are featuring Iran and boy, the Iranian food tonight was slammin. I had the KooKoo Sibzamini and I wish there was just ooooone more patty of onion and potato. It was awesome! My friend had the Mast-o Laboo and mixed it with her kebab and loved it. They also hand out a little pamphlet of information on Iran so you can learn more about it. Keep it up, y'all.

I love the concept for this place and the food is generally very good.

Currently the theme is Native American cuisine. I tried the venison entree, wild greens salad, cornbread, baked beans, and dessert dumplings in berry compote/sauce. Everything was delicious - especially the venison which just fell off the bone. I loved the baked beans, too, with the meaty chunks of bacon. The salad was just okay, but everything else was a little more unique and very tasty. Definitely check out Conflict Kitchen for this food right now!

Oh my! I haven't been here in awhile. I came here today for Iranian food, it was amazing! I got one of their main dish that's chicken with pomegranate marinade. I love it! And I got their almond Persian cookies for dessert! My stomach was happy after that :) I definitely want to come back and check out other cuisine they have.

What an amazing concept. I've had foods from so many countries and nations because of this endeavor. Another place that helps make Pittsburgh great by bringing understanding through the one thing that connects all humans; food.
Had their Persian food, a fairly sweet chicken dish with some herbs adorning it. I'm not well-versed in Persian cuisine but I did enjoy the dish; it's a bit pricey at nine bucks but enjoyable.

I love the original concept of this take-out stand!

My husband read about Conflict Kitchen and insisted we try it during our Pittsburgh visit. I was extremely intrigued, especially when he told me the menu is constantly changing and we may have the chance to try a crazy new ethnic dish. 

My one disappointment: after nine years living in FL, Cuban food had become a standard dining option in my life. Man! I was hoping for a dish from Syria or Iran - something I would more than likely have no opportunity to try elsewhere. It was bad timing on our part.

However, I DO appreciate a quality meal and there was no way we were leaving without trying Conflict Kitchen. I was not disappointed! I ordered the Yuca con Mojo, a Cuban dish I had never tried (score!) and it was GOOD! The dish was very fresh and flavorful. My husband ordered the Picadillo (ground beef with olives, peppers, raisins and tomatoes) and ate every last bite. Good stuff!

I can't wait until our next visit to Pittsburgh and (hopefully) a new menu to try at Conflict Kitchen!

The wife and I went for lunch here one day after church. We were very excited because we love cuban food and the fact my wife is part cuban adds to our love for the food. I feel that Conflict Kitchen did a fairly good rendition of many of the Cuban dishes we tried . 

They have a few entrees and sides choices which we ordered a few of each. Two meals and two side cost us about $23 which isn't bad and was plenty of food. Even though my wife's picadillo is better than that of Conflict Kitchen I give the restaurant two thumbs up. 

Also the fact that they change the food based on countries under conflict is pretty unique. If they stay true to the foods of other ethnic groups as they have Cuba it will be worth it to visit here whenever they switch countries and then some.

this place closed!!! it is now mesa mexican cuisine. very disappointing!!! I came all the way from Chicago to try this place out. Still shows up on maps, still has a website, and still on here. I hear that its because of threats and bad publicity that they closed. People need to calm down!!! I hope they decide to open this concept in Chicago!?!?!

Where is the sixth star.
No joke.
This place is doing everything right - they're doing it because they give a flip, they're using mad skills and ACTUALLY TRAVELING to perfect their recipes and delivering the best product possible. And boy, is it yummy. I've had the Persian and Cuban iterations, as well as taking part in a live SKype meal with Tehran over a full-course, home-cooked Persian meal that blew everyone's mind (the talk? the food? THE GRAMMAR? Let's just say all of it!).
Please live forever.
